text:
Back in February of 2019, I released a video
entitled “Building my Dream Computer.”

In that video I made the case for making a
modern 8 or 16 bit computer made from all
off the shelf components.

Since we don’t have the rights to the Commodore
brand name, I had given it a temporary code-name

of Commander 16. After all, Commander has
the same number of syllables and same number

of letters, and the two words actually have
similar meanings. Despite being a temporary

code name, that name turned out to be quite
popular, so we decided to keep it. However,

we were concerned about people abbreviating
it to C16, which might be easily confused

with the Commodore 16, which is a very different
product. So, we changed the name to Commander

X16 so that people would abbreviate it X16
instead.

And so, I’m going to give you an update
on what has transpired over the last 6 months.

And, the first priority was to find a working
video chip, even if it was temporary.

In the last video I showed the Gameduino being
used in a little adapter card on the user

port. This actually worked fine and it allowed
me to do some experimentation with low-level

SPI programming as well as kernel development.
Kevin ended up making a custom board for me

that had the gameduino integrated onto the
board. I was able to get the board working

on the C64, and with slight modifications
to the code, I also had it working on the
VIC-20.

The graphics capabilities of the Gameduino
are far superior to the Commodore 64, which

was one of my requirements for a video chip.
However, it did lack a true bitmap mode, which

concerned a lot of people. I wasn’t terribly
concerned since it had so many sprites you

could use them together to create a pseudo
bitmap mode for those sort of games that needed

it. Still, this wasn’t the biggest hurdle
to overcome. The biggest problem was speed.

It uses an SPI interface, which is not ideal
for an 8-bit system. I had asked the community

if anyone could modify the gameduino to work
on an 8-bit system bus and there were a few

volunteers for the job. But it turns out the
Gameduino was designed on an obsolete Spartan

3 and not that many people were familiar with
it. And so, this product hung in the balance

for some time as to whether or not it would
be the final video chip.

Another problem we faced is with the 65816
processor. I had originally said I wanted

to use this processor because it had a 24-bit
address bus and could therefor address up

to 16 megabytes of RAM. However, this presented
another problem. You see, the 6502 has 16

address lines. These are the lines it uses
to tell the rest of the system which byte

of RAM its currently working with. And it
has 8 data lines. These are the lines that

allow it to read and write a byte of RAM somewhere
in the system. Well let’s look at the 65816.

It has the same number of pins as the 6502.
It also has 16 address and 8 data lines. But

in order to address 16 megabytes of RAM, it
should technically have 24 address lines.

So where are they? Well, it shares them with
the data lines. Yes, these 8 data lines alternate

during the clock cycle to be data lines or
the upper 8 address lines. This behavior is

extremely annoying and requires a lot of external
circuitry to decode this and split it out.

The board had already gotten complex due to
this, but things continued to get worse. You

see, I never really wanted to use any FPGAs
on the system to begin with. But I conceded

that we would have to for the video chip.
But before long, some of the guys working

on the board design ended up having 3 FPGAs
on the board, along with all other sorts of

complex things like DMA controllers. And at
some point I just started to feel like this

project had allowed feature creep to spiral
out of control and it really no longer resembled
the system I originally wanted.

I also had a strong belief that this board
would wind up still born.

To illustrate the problem, imagine you have
10 components. And you can’t test component

A without all of the rest of the components
working. And you can’t test component B

without all of the other components working,
and so on. This means that if you make any

mistake anywhere, the whole board won’t
work and it will be impossible to figure out

which part is not working. At this point I
was really becoming skeptical that this project

was ever going to work. And even if it did,
it really no longer lined up with my original
goal.

And just to reiterate, I just wanted a computer
that was similar to the Commodore 64 but made

from all off the shelf components and probably
a little bit more powerful.

Then one day I was cleaning up my studio room
and I came across this VIC-20 motherboard

I had been using to test chips in a few months
earlier. I started looking at the board and

had an epiphany. I realized that every single
chip and component on this board is still

available today, except for the video chip
itself. I sat there and thought about it for

a while and realized we could essentially
build a VIC-20. This would mean going back

to the 6502 processor. Of course, our VIC-20
would have a lot more RAM, better video, and

better audio. So, it wouldn’t have any of
the shortcomings of the VIC-20. But it would

have the advantage that it is a known working
design, which greatly reduces the amount of
untested features.

The VIC-20 design also has another important
aspect, it’s super simple. And that was

always one of my goals. I wanted the computer
to be easy enough for a single person to understand

the whole board, and I wanted it to be easy
to program. Just as an example, if you look

at the C64 memory map, the first 32K is pretty
easy to use, but then the rest of the RAM

is all shared with different things. And using
the last 12K of RAM is actually a real pain
in the rear.

By comparison, if you look at the VIC-20 memory
map, there is no banking. Everything stays

exactly where it is all of the time. The bad
news is that you can usually only get about

32K of RAM in a VIC-20. So obviously we would
need some way to increase that. I also need

to explain how a VIC-20 or C64 handle their
video RAM. You see, the memory in these computers

runs a 2 mhz. And the CPU takes turns with
the video chip accessing the RAM on alternating

clock cycles. So the CPU runs effectively
at 1 mhz. This also means you need to have

room in your memory map for video RAM and
character ROM. However, since our video chip

will use its own RAM this whole setup is unnecessary.
This frees up a lot of the design.

When you look at the crystal that runs a Commodore
64 or VIC-20, the speed of these crystals

is often based on the NTSC or PAL signal frequency.
So, for example, the NTSC version of the C64

has a clock crystal running just over 14 mhz.
This signal is divided up with logic chips

to produce the the color sub-carrier frequency,
the dot-clock, the memory bus speed, and eventually

the CPU speed, which as I mentioned runs half
of the memory bus speed because it alternates

cycles with the video chip. It’s also important
to realize that other chips like the SID-chip

and the CIA chips have timers and all work
off of those frequencies as well. That is

why it is nearly impossible to overclock a
computer like this, as all of these things

are dependent on that main clock signal, and
messing with any one of them can cause significant
problems.

However, since the Commander X16 will be using
VGA and the video chip is going to have its

own clock, the speed of the CPU is less constrained.
The 65c02 is technically rated at 14 mhz,

but we knew there would be other chips on
the board that might present a bottleneck

such as the RAM and ROM. So the goal was to
run it at 8 Mhz. Failing that, I’d be totally

happy with 4 mhz, and could even live with
2 mhz if it came down to it.

As such, this is the memory map I came up
with. You get almost 40K of base memory, which

we are calling “low memory” in our design.
And then over here we have another 8K. But

what makes this area special, is that it is
banked. And the banking system for this is

so much simpler than what the C64 uses. You
see, there are 256 banks of 8K each, giving

a total memory area of 2 megabytes. We are
calling this area the high memory area. The

entire 16K ROM area also banks, as there are
8 possible banks for this, allowing us to

cram a lot of built in application into the
system.

Now there are some things I should mention
about this design. A lot of people will look

at this 39K area here and say “that’s
all?” But the reality is, this is more than

a lot of people might realize. For one thing,
this RAM is all available. Other similar computers

of the era would also have to incorporate
video RAM into this area, which could be a

lot if graphics mode were to be used. As I
mentioned, we don’t need that since our

video RAM is separate. Second of all, our
computer doesn’t need to load any sort of

DOS into RAM like an Apple II, Atari, or IBM
would have needed to do.

Another consideration is that BASIC requires
contiguous memory area. Which means this area

here is all that can be used by BASIC directly,
so it will have a similar amount of available

BASIC RAM as a Commodore 64, which boots up
with 38K free. And to be honest, I’ve almost

never seen anyone use up the entire 38K in
a BASIC program. It’s actually really hard
to do.

I’d like to draw your attention to the memory
map I showed for Planet X2 a while back. The

entire game code actually fit in the first
16K section of RAM. Actually, I think the

game code was really something more like 13K.
All of the rest of the RAM was used for things

like graphics, music, play field map, and
variable data. If I were to design that game

for this computer, for example, I would be
able to use this entire area for code, which

is 3 times larger than what I had available
on the Commodore 64. And all of the other
data could go into this banked area.

Now, let me explain how these RAM banks are
controlled. It is ridiculously simple. We

have taken one of the 6522 chips and used
an entire 8-bit I/O area and connected these

to the upper address lines of the RAM chips.
So, you can literally just type POKE 40801

and then any number between 0 to 255 to select
your RAM bank. Or, if you were doing this

in assembly language, you would just need
two commands, LDA with your RAM bank number,

and then STA $9F61. So, it is super fast and
easy to select RAM banks and there is up to
2 MB of high RAM available.

Once we had a plan for the board, then we
really needed a better long-term video chip

solution. So, I reached out to the community
to some people who were FPGA experts to see
if they could design a custom video chip.

I only had a few requirements. I said I wanted
it to output VGA video. I wanted it to use

its own RAM. And I wanted it to interface
to the system bus through 4 registers. So,

it would essentially occupy 4 bytes of system
RAM. The first byte is the auto-increment

value, I’ll explain this in a moment. Next
you have the high address byte, and the low

address byte. And last you have the read/write
byte. So if you wanted to write to the first

byte of video RAM, you would set these two
values to zero, and then you could write the

value you wanted to put in there to this register.
You can also read this register to find out
what byte is in there.

Now, at first this would appear to be slower
to use than a setup like the C64 where the

video RAM is shared with the CPU. However,
that’s where this auto-increment byte comes

in handy. If you set this byte to 1, then
every time you write a byte to this register,

the value in these registers will automatically
increase by one. So, you can set the starting

location and just keep writing bytes one after
the next. This means that when doing block

copies of data to and from the video chip,
it is actually just about as fast, and in

some cases faster, than using shared video
RAM.

I actually ended up getting working submissions
from two different people. Ross Andrews sent

me this daughter board here which we code
named Project Vulcan. And Frank Van de Hoef

sent me this little video board codenamed
project Vera. In the beginning these boards

only had text modes, which was fine because
I said that’s all we needed to get started

as long as the bus interface worked. Both
of these boards worked so we ended up having

to select one going forward, which wasn’t
an easy decision. We ended up selecting the

Vera chip for the long-term. Frank had already
designed a small single board computer he

called Koneko, which means kitten in Japanese.
It already had working VGA output. So he was

able to use a lot of that experience to design
the Vera chip.

One of the first things we needed to do was
get the Vera chip connected to a Commodore

64 so that we could start testing things.
Kevin built this little board where the Vera

daughterboard can just connect in like this,
and then we can plug in a VGA monitor and

plug it into the C64’s cartridge port. Of
course, it didn’t work first time. As always

with these things, it took a bit of debugging.
But we did eventually get it working and you

can see it here working on the C64. It was
really important to be able to see the chip

working on a C64, not only so we could prove
that the FPGA design worked and was compatible

with a 6502 processor, but also so we could
start developing kernel code that would eventually

make its way into the final production board.
In fact, we’ve talked about making this

into a separate product for C64 users once
all of the FPGA design is complete, which

would give all of the Commander X16’s video
features to C64 users. Or heck even VIC-20
and PET users for that matter.

So what is this Vera chip capable of? Well,
for starters it has several text modes starting

with the 80x60 mode, and can go all the way
down to a VIC-20 like resolution of 20x15.

Text mode works in 16 colors, with a user
definable palette, although the default palette

mimics the Commodore 64. However, unlike the
Commodore 64, you can define both foreground

and background color for each character. There
is also a 256 color text mode, as well as

special tile modes. There is also a 4 color,
16 color, and 256 color bit map mode, with

a master palette of 4,096 colors to choose
from. It also has features such as smooth

scrolling, multiple layers, and sprites. It
also has 128K of dedicated video RAM. This

will put the Commander X16’s video capabilities
very much in line with the Amiga, actually

superior in many ways. And even superior to
VGA graphics as well. This is actually far

more than I really ever even wanted for the
system. But the main thing is, it works.

Now, at this point the main people working
on this project was evenly split between myself

doing kernel development, Kevin Williams doing
the board design, and Frank Van de Hoef doing

the video chip. However, in searching for
help with the Kernal, I ended up contacting

Michael Steil, who is an expert with the Commodore
Kernal and he became excited about the project

and so he jumped on board. And to be honest,
most of the heavy lifting in this project

is now being done by these 3 people. And so
while this is still my dream computer, don’t

for a moment think that I’m designing this
by myself. In fact, quite the opposite.

In fact, I have somebody working on a custom
case, and two different keyboard solutions

including a low-end keyboard and a high-end
keyboard with mechanical switches, and a user

manual. And that person would be Christian
Simpson, better known as Perifractic.

Thank you so much, the 9-bit guy. The extra
bit is for parity, right? She’s bored already.

But yes, Perifractic here from retro recipes.
And you may know my channel for puppyfractic,

or ladyfractic’s repairs. Or of course,
for my full sized working lego Commodore 64,

the “brixty-four,” which I designed and
built. And it’s on the subject of design

is why I was brought on board to the Commander
X16 team.

So, basically, me and my small design department,
which is Puppyfractic, and my braw Scottish

friend Gaz Marshall, we’re heading up the
exterior design team. And the first challenge

we set ourselves was looking at the logo.
So, basically, I see the Commander X16 as

being about rebirth. You know, it’s the
first of a new breed of retro machines. And

it was about the time we were looking at the
logo design that we had this butterfly invasion

here in California. So here is the Commander
X16 butterfly logo.

As you can see, we tried to incorporate modern
elements like those sharp cutting edges and

the modern font. But with the juxtaposition
of the old school color gradient. And we were

able to work with David to take a version
of that logo to the BASIC screen. But what

else can we put the logo on? Well, that brings
us neatly to the subject of the case.

And in this case, pun intended, I didn’t
want to re-invent the wheel. There are so

many great cases out there already that we
could actually rebrand, rewrap, and customize.

So, that’s what I’m doing. And I’m already
working with a company on that. And here’s

the first sample. So, this is going to be
for the mini ITX version which is going to

be released a little way down the line. And
we’re going to re-wrap this. Here’s a

couple of the mockups of what we have in mind.
And, as part of this design process, I consulted

with R. Nicholas Jensen, who is known for
some of his incredible retro designs. Now,

Micro is weirdly bigger than mini, although
Ladyfractic assures me that size doesn’t

matter. But, we are going to need a micro
ATX case first. So, I’ve also worked on

a design for that and here’s the mockup
of it. We’re not sure which color to go

yet. We’ll probably put this to a poll on
the facebook group. We might even go full

retro and make the whole thing beige, kind
of like an Apple IIgs. But either way, right

now, you can see that it kind of looks like
an old book that you might find in a grand

library somewhere. We want people to learn
from this machine. Either way, with this we

try to embody the retro meets modern feel,
with those blue LEDs shining through the old.

And I’ve kind of put a little Easter egg
nod there. Or a tap on the shoulder. On that

front panel, it doesn’t just show you where
the power button is; if you read it a certain

way it actually says 8-Bit Power! And to me,
a lot of that power comes from the nostalgia.

But this case won’t just be nostalgic. We’re
going to make sure that in the back you’ve

got lots of room for expandability and any
of your own hacks you want to do.

So What about the keyboard? Well, again, we’re
going down a standard route, but rebranding

and rewrapping it so you get the best of both
worlds. Here’s a little mockup of how it

might look with those PETSCII characters in
place and the logo on the top. And also on

the team we’re lucky to have Andrew Owen,
yeah you like him, right? He’s looking at

the possibility of a deluxe, all singing,
all dancing, keyboard using cherry MX micro
switches. She loves those.

That just leaves the user guide. And for this,
my one prerequisite is that it must be spiral

bound. I know David is in agreement with that.
So, we’re already well into the process

of producing that. And it will be kind of
like the old-school VIC-20 user guide or the

BASIC programming guides of the eighties,
with lots of illustrations and easy to follow

along BASIC programs. Well, that’s about
it for the updates on the exterior design.

OK, all right, I put a treat in there you
can take it. Do follow along on the facebook

group, though, because I do post updates there
and polls asking for your opinion from time

to time. And I might even post some updates
on my youtube channel. But, for now, for me

and Puppyfractic, back to you in the studio,
the 8-Bit Murray. Bye.

OK, thank you, Perifractic! Now, let’s talk
about sound chips for a moment. So, this was

a really difficult decision because I wanted
a chip that was still in production, and that

would interface with a 6502 processor, and
was easy to program for.

Now what I mean by easy to program, is if
you look at the Commodore VIC-20, which is

the computer I learned to program on. I could
simply POKE a value to one of the 4 sound

generators, and immediately get sound. It
was that easy. When moving to the Commodore

64, however, making the SID chip do anything
required a lot of setup, which was often annoying

when I just wanted a beep or two. However,
much like the video situation, there really

wasn’t much available that seemed appropriate.
We ended up selecting the General Instruments

AY-3-8910, which is the same sound chip used
in a lot of systems from the 80s including

the Sinclair Spectrum, Intellivision, Vectrex,
MSX computers, the Mockingboard for the Apple

II series computers, and the Atari ST. And
while these are inferior to the SID chip found

in the C64, we figured we could partially
make up for that by including two chips, giving

us 6 voices. And here’s a sample of what
that might sound like.

You can find lots more samples on Youtube
and Soundcloud if you want.

So to test these chips, Kevin also designed
a board for the C64’s cartridge port that

has two of the AY-3 chips on board. As you
can see, it has the two AY-3 chips and what

you can’t see is underneath each chip is
a digital-to-analog converter, or DAC. So

that gives stereo digital output as well.
I wrote a sample program where I can test

the various voices of the chips like this.
It doesn’t do anything terribly impressive,

but it allows me to test the function of all
6 voices. There wasn’t a lot of existing

code to use since the AY-3 chips were rarely
ever used in 6502 based computers. Anyway,

everything was looking promising with these
chips, but in the end we had to abandon them,
which I’ll talk more about later.

So, now I want to talk about my master plan.
So, much like Elon Musk had a master plan

to introduce mass market electric vehicles
in 3 different stages, I also have 3 different

stages I’m working on. So, originally, I
had suggested that I wanted to be able to

sell this product for $50. Unfortunately,
that’s not going to happen. At least not
at stage one.

The first product will be a motherboard designed
for a Micro-ATX style case. The board will

be all DIP package just like a vintage computer.
It will be very hackable. It will have expansion

slots so you can add cards and other hardware.
This first board is going to lay the foundation

of the architecture and it will be aimed at
hardware and software developers. And it’s

going to be kind of expensive. I don’t know
an exact price at this point, but I’m thinking

somewhere between $200 and $300. I can’t
get more exact because we haven’t finalized

the hardware and we even found a company to
manufacture it. In fact, we may be looking

at selling the board by itself, or possibly
getting a custom case manufactured. It may

even be sold as a kit that the end user can
assemble. So there are a lot of unknowns.

The second stage of this development would
be to build a second board that uses smaller

surface mount parts. This would reduce the
size and cost of the board, as well as most

likely the cost of assembly. It would most
likely be aimed at a mini-ITX style board,
and be far less expandable and less hackable.

But, I still don’t think that would put
us anywhere near the $50 price range I had

initially suggested. For that, we would need
to condense the entire thing down to maybe

a single FPGA with a RAM chip or something.
And if there is enough demand, maybe even

a custom ASIC. At this point you’d have
something about the size of a Raspberry Pi.

So that is the end goal, and whether we get
there or not will depend greatly on how the
first two stages go.

OK, so I’ve got Kevin Williams from TexElec
back with us again, and he is the main designer

behind the Commander 16 prototype board and
we’ve got our first prototype. So, these

were actually made by PCBWay. They’ve been
following this project with enthusiasm and

they offered to make our first 10 prototype
boards for free and so big thanks to out to

PCBWay. Yeah, they’re great boards, good
quality, they’re going to serve us well

for this project. All right so, I’ve going
to have Kevin give you a little overview of
these finished boards.

This is the first fully populated board that
we built to do some testing and in this empty

slot right here is actually where the Vera
video is meant to be installed. Before we

installed this module initially, however,
we wrote some sample assembly code to do some

various tests like flash an LED, test the
memory decode logic, as well as the IO select

logic. And once we had written enough code
to feel fairly comfortable that the processor

was operating and doing what it was supposed
to do, we moved into the next phase, which

was to test the Vera video module. Unfortunately,
that is when we discovered our first issue,

the module is actually being installed backwards
due to a bit of a miscommunication between

Frank and I, and after we determined OK, let’s
move that module to the bottom, I then discovered

however, that the PS/2 port also had a mirrored
image. So, this is the board that we actually

wound up starting to use. As you can see,
the video header is on the bottom as well

as the PS/2 keyboard port. And now, we just
have to install the board. And this is another

board that we made. It’s actually the same
as the green one. It’s just a different

color. And now we have a machine fully ready
to run.

Let’s just walk around the board real quick
and show the different ports and features

that are available. First on the right here
we have the Commodore IEC serial port which

is also used for printers and floppy drive
on Commodore 64s and Vic-20s. I also have

a header on here. Initially I didn’t have
the connector, but we decided to go ahead

and add both of them so we could plug in an
SD-2-IEC or any other floppy drive as we get

further into development. Next, you’ll notice
the dreaded 7805 regulator that everyone hates.

I put that on there just because I have a
lot of them. Ultimately the board will be

powered by ATX so the barrel connector and
the large capacitor will be a thing of the

past. They are just here for our prototype.
On the back of the board, there are actually

3 different connectors that were initially
designed for video. We only have two of them

populated at the moment. The 3rd is S-Video.
That’s actually planned to come back at

some point but for the moment we don’t have
the connector installed. The others are of

course, VGA, and composite video. Next is
the PS/2 keyboard which is also installed

upside-down as we previously discussed, but
working great. Lastly is the audio jack on

this side as far as external connectors go.
That will allow you to hear the sound from
the AY-3 chips.

Let me turn the board. On the back of the
board, we have 4 expansion headers that we

put in pace just for us to test other functions
and other things that we might want to add

after the final board. These aren’t going
to be representative of what the final has,

they will actually be much larger and actually
lined up to where they will fit in a Mini

ITX ATX style case. Just below those are the
AY-3-8910 chips. Unfortunately, these won’t

be in the final product. They’re just simply
not going to work fast enough to run at 8

Mhz, but you’ll see 2 small header expansion
pins here. The AY-3 chips themselves have

2 ports much like a VIA or a 6522 chip would
have. One port is connected to a DAC on either

one. And the other is just open. Unfortunately
we will have to migrate this. The LCD screen

was originally installed as a way for us to
have some sort of video before the VERA chip

was complete. However as we competed the design
of the motherboard and had them manufactured,

the Vera board was actually compete right
around the same time. So, as a result of that,

the LCD will also be removed from the final
board. But, for the moment it works so we

left it on there just to play with it. And
later, its certainly something that could

be built into an expansion port if you desired
to do so.

So, let’s talk a little about what chips
are actually on the board. As you can see

here, is the 6502 CPU, and just above it is
the first of 6522 VIA chips. These are the

peripheral style chips similar to what the
VIC-20 has. And there’s the second VIA chip

up here as well. And just to it you’ll see
a small expansion port that says USER port.

These pins are actually very similar to the
user port on a Commodore VIC-20 or Commodore

64. Just to the right of that are the two
jumper settings that control the master clock

signals for the system. As well for the AY-3.
We actually have a 16 megahertz crystal and

two chips that just divide down to different
frequencies. We can actually set the master

clock anywhere between 16 and 1 mhz and the
AY3 clock with the 16 megahertz crystal from

4 down to 1 megahertz as well. This won’t
be on the final board either. It’s really

for us to test and as you can see we’re
actually running at 2 megahertz right now.

And there’s some various reasons for that,
